intro: Conocarpus erectus var. arboreus, commonly known as the white mangrove, is a species of flowering plant in the family Rhizophoraceae. It is characterized by its ability to thrive in saline and tidal environments, making it a common inhabitant of coastal regions. The plant has a distinctive appearance with smooth, grayish bark and small, oval-shaped leaves that are often covered in a waxy cuticle. Its flowers are typically pale green or white, and it produces small, round fruits that contain a single seed. This species plays an important ecological role in stabilizing coastal soils and providing habitat for various marine and terrestrial organisms.
